content.description: Very cool arete climbing on knobs and edges.  Classic arete climbing using both sides of the arete make it worth doing despite the steep ground at the base.
content.location: Not really on the Murray Wall but close enough to include.  From the campsite reached just before the Murray Wall drop down the hill to the left maybe 100 feet.  You can't miss the overhanging arete.

content.description: Thin technical face climbing to a bulge finishing on a airy buttress.
content.location: Start just below the big pine on smooth looking slab.

content.description: Face climbing to large quartz crystals and knobs.
content.protection: Bolts & chains.  Shares anchors with "Oreos & Promises".
content.location: Third climb from the left on the backside.

content.description: Thin start to bulge then groove which you stay a bit left of.  Same anchors as for Tiger Paw which is the first route right of the big pine tree.  David's 1st FA, ground up, drilling on lead.
content.location: Second route right of the big pine tree.

content.description: Thin face climbing on knobs and crystals similar to routes in Needles of South Dakota.
content.location: On the downhill side of the Murray Wall at the Ravens.  Climb the prominent rib up the gully from the pine tree.

content.description: Face climbing on crystals to bigger holds above.
content.protection: Bolts & chains.  Shares anchors with "Tiger Teeth".

content.description: Climb face to large flake/crack. Shares chains with School of Hard Rocks, which is to the next line to the right.
content.location: The first line right of the big tree on the back side of Murray Wall, meaning its the second line from the left once you go around the backside and up the gully.

content.description: This is an interesting climb.  I feel like this could be lumped into the "warm-up for The Orifice" category.  I found it a bit harder than Mandatory Doug Testing.  The climbing is also a little less straight forward which makes for more interesting climbing.
content.location: Just left of Kundalini Express, which shares the start with Mandatory Doug Testing.

climbs.name: Mandatory Doug Testing
climbs.fa: EFR, Kevin Carmichael, Doug Lantz, and Diane Vetter

content.description: Slightly overhanging with bigger holds.  A good warm up for the better climbs at the crag.  Climb ends in a deep crack.
content.location: Located in the middle of the cliff.  Is very evident by the deep crack near the top which you climb into/ around as you finish the climb

content.description: Shares start with Mandatory Drug Testing then goes left to the obvious seam. Probably the best climb on the wall.
content.location: Obvious inviting seam somewhat left of the center of the crag.

content.description: Getting up the face to the crack will get your attention.  This route needs to get bolted and it will when time and funds permit.
content.protection: None although some big cams could be used in the the crack.
content.location: Starts between the 3rd route right of the pine tree and Scratching post.  Climbs face to hueco like feature.

climbs.name: Forever in Bluejeans
climbs.fa: Mike Argueso, probably first toproped by Bob Murray and others.

content.description: Very sporty climbing up the slightly overhanging face leads to a deep cleft and rest before finishing out the last bit of pebble pinching to the chains.
Steep start that traverses left then up to a steep headwall.  The trick is getting to the quartz crystals that lead to lower angle rock.
content.location: From the campsite just before you get to the Murray wall proper, drop down and left about 100 feet.  Overhanging crystal and knob covered face that is severely undercut just left of an obvious flake.

content.description: Great stemming in the middle and a stout finish.
content.location: Third route right of the big pine tree.

content.description:
Holding nothing back, Countdown To Ecstasy starts with powerful edging and crimping.  This sequence demands technique and forces interesting movement.  A sinker pocket and deep undercling provide a respite at the third bolt.  Surmount two bulges separated by seemingly blank face.  Finish by following a near horizontal crack to the anchor. 

Countdown To Ecstasy has long been a personal mystery.  The route ascends interesting features but sees little traffic in comparison to its neighbors.  A rumor swirled that the line was plagued by poor rock.  My intrigue and completest tendencies finally got the better of me. 

  The rock quality is good but not great.  The bottom shows signs of features lost, the upper headwall is a bit grainy, and the final horizontal crack has an easily avoidable hold that flexes.  Clipping the second bolt, while likely safe, held my attention as the easiest clipping stance comes after the sequence in near groundfall territory.  With those caveats the movement and features on this line make it worth exploring.
content.protection: 6 bolts to 2 bolts, which are not anchor bolts.  Since lowering directly through these bolts may damage the rope, leaver biners were added September 2014.  While I have not personally confirmed, it may be possible to walk off as well.
content.location: Countdown To Ecstasy is the rightmost line on the front face of The Murray Wall.  Said another way it is the furthest west route on the northwest face.  Two routes start downhill, past a tree, from the others: Cracked Rhythm on the left; and Countdown to Ecstasy on the right.

content.description: WARNING:110 feet long face climb with a slab start and two bulges up high.  fun climbing with a long very easy run out in the middle.  You can get off with a 60M rope if you stop lowering when the climber reaches the ledge just below the first bolt.  Be careful not to drop your partner!
content.location: As you approach the moderate routes on the SE side of the Murray Wall,  at the toe of the cliff just before you start up the gully that leads to Scratching Post and the other routes, 3rd class up easy ramp to bolted face with crystals.

content.description: A 20 foot boulder problem, but not a bad boulder problem.

This is a great summer area.  Not only is it nice and cool because its at the top, but it is also in the shade for a good portion of the day.  You are unlikely to see many other people here, and if you do it is likely they are hiking out to the Fortress and not stopping to climb the few routes that are here.  If you've not climbed up this high on Mt. Lemmon you will be surprised to see that the rock is different.  It is very much like the rock in Tuolomne Meadows in YNP.      You can toprope most of these climbs by accessign the top of the cliff.      This area is affected by the Pergrine Falcon closure that applies to the other summit crags.
